CF62E2878E1B414BAF5AEA9D5BFB6068.description: Adhere to the idea of the simultaneous complexity and simplicity of physical reality.

B9C231DB93A44C5CBFE1BDAD821358B1.description: Share concern and care for the environment as part of God’s creation.

2CDB91DC624D4182B9B443716B47F696.description:
Subscribe to the premise that nature should not be manipulated at will, but should be respected for its natural
purpose and end as destined by the creator God.

AAECEF3AE28540C0A694C972445A14D8.description:
Share how natural phenomena have more than a utilitarian meaning and purpose and exemplify the handiwork of
the Creator.

B979B70DCDE64FA5AA485EC4D7E6D53A.description: Display a deep sense of wonder and delight about the natural universe.

67D9942CD66D4B31AE23E96E810AE56A.description:
Demonstrate an understanding of the moral issues involving in vitro fertilization, human cloning, human genetic
manipulation, and human experimentation and what the Church teaches regarding work in these areas.

BC61691140EF4D238F2FD0E70ED1E5B6.description: Articulate the details of the Galileo affair to counter the assumption that the Church is anti-science.

FCE4EF13566348C19240205025CB6973.description:
Explain the supernatural design hypothesis in terms of the Borde-Vilenkin-Guth Proof, the Second Law of
Thermodynamics, entropy, and anthropic coincidences (fine tuning of initial conditions and universal constants)
(see Appendix E).

7CBE235E3CFB474DB8D0AC047B25DFEF.description:
Explain how understanding the physiological properties of a human being does not address the existence of the
transcendent spirit of the human person (see Appendix E).

40BD34F852464FDB947770D75A486562.description:
Relate how the human soul is specifically created by God for each human being, does not evolve from lesser matter,
and is not inherited from our parents.

ACBDDDD82E084B0FA86ACF55EA5077CC.description: Analyze and articulate the Church’s approach to the theory of evolution.

C0115AA3AA7049D78C11E9A41073AB50.description:
Identify key Catholic scientists such as Copernicus, Mendel, DaVinci, Bacon, Pasteur, Volta, St. Albert the Great, and
others and the witness and evidence they supply against the false claim that Catholicism is not compatible with
science.

FD95D6A3136B4F2DA78613125644A97E.description:
Articulate the limitations of science (the scientific method and constraints of the physical world) to know and
understand God and transcendent reality.

6899B3119E5942ADACE4DAEB082C9F10.description:
Distinguish the difference between the use of the scientific method and the use of theological inquiry to know and
understand God’s creation and universal truths.

C10A80FE01F044B78BC32EE042E81979.description:
Evaluate the errors present in the belief system of scientific naturalism or scientism8 (which includes materialism9
and reductionism10), which posits that scientific exploration and explanation is the only valid source of meaning.

C7D08CFF94C7473A91DCE606AC4AB198.description:
Describe humanity’s natural situation in, and dependence upon, physical reality and how man carries out his role
as a cooperator with God in the work of creation.

F34DB229CD4A42C09ADE1F0E7CF7A542.description: Evaluate the relationship between God, man, and nature, and the proper role in the totality of being and creation.

C638C39905CA4EC29AD4D4861A2E1219.description:
Explain the processes of conservation, preservation, overconsumption, and stewardship as it relates to creation
and to caring for that which God has given to sustain and delight us.

BB9657CDE3B44ACA88BD6BDCBBB6A79B.description:
Relate how the search for truth, even when it concerns a finite reality of the natural world or of man, is neverending
and always points beyond to something higher than the immediate object of study.

3C9AE70F9B274A5DB2F55D6CAF38909B.description:
Analyze how the pursuit of scientific knowledge, for utilitarian purposes alone or for the misguided manipulation
of nature, thwarts the pursuit of authentic Truth and the greater glory of God.

8BC93C3B6C474FE7B0CEFFCF5883526D.description:
Demonstrate confidence in human reason and in one’s ability to know the truth about God’s creation and the
fundamental intelligibility of the world.

400045BFE3BA46A38B0ED37C5D7F50E1.description:
Articulate how science properly situates itself within other academic disciplines (e.g., history, theology) for
correction and completion in order to recognize the limited material explanation of reality to which it is properly
attuned.

6FE1B0FD7D5B49989602A2351A94A85F.description: Share how the beauty and goodness of God is reflected in nature and the study of the natural sciences.

818AC180201F41F7B036F366B03E1909.description: Value the human body as the temple of the Holy Spirit

54CAE9E5D09745CCB286842DC405D827.description:
Explain and promote the unity of faith and reason with confidence that there exists no contradiction between the
God of nature and the God of the faith.

043C08F3E86E470890DD06D5C2B64317.description: Exhibit a primacy of care and concern at all stages of life for each human person as an image and likeness of God.
